title: mighty standard component
text: vignette provides step--step guide creating standard components {mighty} framework. following conventions using custom roxygen2 tags, create components consistent, well-documented, easily integrated existing ecosystem.

title: mighty standard component
text: {mighty} framework, “component” function processes input data returns modified version new columns rows. Standard components share common structure documentation pattern, facilitating use inside {mighty}.

title: mighty standard component
text: package extends standard {roxygen2} special “Mighty” tags help document specialized functions. tags enable: Clear identification function types Explicit declaration data dependencies Documentation output variables available tags always required :

title: mighty standard component
text: Standard components follow conventions: first parameter always named .self (input dataset) Additional parameters represent datasets configuration options function returns modified .self dataset new variables function documented using standard {roxygen2} tags custom tags mentioned Documentation includes specific information type, dependencies, outputs Include example using appropriate data {pharmaversesdtm} {pharmaverseadam} new component corresponding unit test

title: mighty standard component
text: Every component follow basic structure:
code: #' Component title #' @description #' A short description of what the component does... #' #' @param .self `data.frame` Input dataset #' @param param1 Other parameters as needed #' @param param2 Other parameters as needed #' #' @type [component type] #' @depends [input dependencies: {data} {variable}] #' @outputs [output variables: One entry per new variable] #' #' @returns `.self` with added/modified variables #' @export your_new_component <- function(.self, param1, param2) {   # Implementation that transforms .self   # ...   return(.self) }

title: mighty standard component
text: Let’s examine real example: generates following roxygen documentation custom “Mighty” appears standard roxygen sections:
code: #' Dummy component creating a Albumin grouping variable #' @description #' Based on the baseline readings (`ABLFL == "Y"`) for Albumin #' (`PARAMCD == "ALB"`) a new grouping variable (`ALBBLGRP`) is #' added with the following intervals: #' #' * Albumin levels at least 40 g/L: ">= 40 g/L" #' * Albumin levels below 40 g/L: "< 40 g/L" #' * Missing or no baseline levels: "Missing" #' #' @param .self `data.frame` Input #' @param adlb `data.frame` ADLB data set #' @type derivation #' @depends .self USUBJID #' @depends adlb USUBJID #' @depends adlb PARAMCD #' @depends adlb AVAL #' @outputs ALBBLGRP #' @returns `.self` with added subject level Albumin grouping at baseline #' @examples #' pharmaverseadam::adsl |> #'   dplyr::select(USUBJID) |> #'   dummy(adlb = pharmaverseadam::adlb) #' #' @export dummy <- function(.self, adlb) {   x <- adlb |>     dplyr::filter(.data$PARAMCD == "ALB", .data$ABLFL == "Y") |>     dplyr::transmute(       .data$USUBJID,       ALBBLGRP = dplyr::case_when(         .data$AVAL >= 40 ~ ">= 40 g/L",         !is.na(.data$AVAL) ~ "< 40 g/L",         TRUE ~ "Missing"       )     )    .self <- .self |>     dplyr::left_join(x, by = "USUBJID") |>     dplyr::mutate(ALBBLGRP = dplyr::coalesce(.data$ALBBLGRP, "Missing"))    return(.self) } % Generated by roxygen2: do not edit by hand % Please edit documentation in mighty.standards/dummy.R \name{dummy} \alias{dummy} \title{Dummy component creating a Albumin grouping variable} \usage{ dummy(.self, adlb) } \arguments{ \item{.self}{`data.frame` Input}  \item{adlb}{`data.frame` ADLB data set} } \value{ `.self` with added subject level Albumin grouping at baseline } \description{ Based on the baseline readings (`ABLFL == "Y"`) for Albumin (`PARAMCD == "ALB"`) a new grouping variable (`ALBBLGRP`) is added with the following intervals:  * Albumin levels at least 40 g/L: ">= 40 g/L" * Albumin levels below 40 g/L: "< 40 g/L" * Missing or no baseline levels: "Missing" } \examples{ pharmaverseadam::adsl |>   dplyr::select(USUBJID) |>   dummy(adlb = pharmaverseadam::adlb)  } \section{Mighty}{ \subsection{Type}{ derivation } \subsection{Depends}{ \itemize{ \item .self.USUBJID \item adlb.USUBJID \item adlb.PARAMCD \item adlb.AVAL } } \subsection{Outputs}{ \itemize{ \item ALBBLGRP } } }

title: Standard derivations for ADaM generation
text: mighty.standards serve repository generic compute components used produce ADaM scripts {mighty} framework.

title: Standard derivations for ADaM generation
text: can install development version mighty.standards GitHub :

title: Standard derivations for ADaM generation
text: Functions inside mighty.standards meant called directly, instead used input mighty framework automatic generation ADaM programs. See vignette("mighty-standards") create new standard components.

code: x <- pharmaversesdtm::ae |>   dplyr::select(USUBJID, AEENDTC) |>   aendt("AEENDTC")  print(x) #> # A tibble: 1,191 × 4 #>    USUBJID     AEENDTC    AENDT      AENDTF #>    <chr>       <chr>      <date>     <chr>  #>  1 01-701-1015 NA         NA         NA     #>  2 01-701-1015 NA         NA         NA     #>  3 01-701-1015 2014-01-11 2014-01-11 NA     #>  4 01-701-1023 NA         NA         NA     #>  5 01-701-1023 2012-08-30 2012-08-30 NA     #>  6 01-701-1023 NA         NA         NA     #>  7 01-701-1023 2012-08-30 2012-08-30 NA     #>  8 01-701-1028 NA         NA         NA     #>  9 01-701-1028 NA         NA         NA     #> 10 01-701-1034 NA         NA         NA     #> # ℹ 1,181 more rows  x |>   dplyr::filter(!is.na(AENDTF)) |>   print() #> # A tibble: 0 × 4 #> # ℹ 4 variables: USUBJID <chr>, AEENDTC <chr>, AENDT <date>, AENDTF <chr>
